stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes and iterates on a sub-area of the Arts & Crafts (cardboard) stage: arranging modular floating platforms that fall when approached, planning saw hazards for a fast "race"-style challenge, and searching for a better floor texture/style. He also discusses emulator/N64 rendering differences (including a rejected idea to shrink Mario’s hat texture on emulator), struggles with Blender-to-engine transform/scale mismatches, and shares strong opinions on speedrunning design and his YouTube-vs-game-making priorities.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains clear design intent for a modular falling-platform sub-area, notable technical friction (Blender scaling/UV + overflow issues, emulator toolchain complaints), and candid statements about speedrun philosophy and why he makes YouTube videos (money) versus the game (passion).

findings.summary: The sub-area concept for the Arts & Crafts/Cardboard level is modular platforming over an "abyss," with cardboard-themed platforms and an intended lava pit below; the player crosses floating platforms while nearby platforms fall away.
Core gameplay hook for this sub-area is a fast-paced "race" feel: saw hazards will activate when Mario gets within a radius, forcing constant movement rather than slow, careful platforming.

Kaze uses per-object parameters (described as "B-params") to scale platform actors for variety, but hit an overflow/underflow issue that he mitigated by adjusting bounds/parameters and by restructuring the setup (e.g., using multiple smaller platforms instead of scaling one large piece).

Scaling platforms in Blender/engine caused unexpected discrepancies (scale and translation behaving differently in Mario 64 than in Blender), leading him to scrap and rebuild the platforms to regain predictable placement.

Texture/UV scaling constraints emerged: scaling did not affect UVs the way he wanted, pushing him toward a more advanced solution (potentially dynamically generating vertices so UV scale matches model scale) rather than relying on simple scaling.

He is actively searching for a floor treatment that reads as "painted"/handcrafted without looking repetitive or visually bad; this stream is framed as a texture-picking/visual-direction session for that floor.

He explored emulator-specific rendering tweaks (idea: use the same hat texture but render it at half-size on emulator to look less "crusty"), but rejected it as looking bad and reinforced a preference against adding many user-facing options just for minor visual complaints.
findings.quote: Less options is better, don’t you ask me.

findings.summary: Kaze wants speedruns to stay recognizable to casual gameplay; he prefers occasional hype skips/BLJs rather than a run dominated by repeated glitches that make the game unrecognizable (citing Sonic speedruns as an example of "too broken").
findings.quote: As soon as the game becomes unrecognizable from how the casual gameplay of the game goes, then the speedrun is not fun anymore.

findings.summary: He expects the finished game’s speedrun times to be substantial if major skips are prevented: he guesses any% could land around 80–85 minutes and 100% around 3–3.5 hours, implying a long-form hack with sustained content rather than a short demo-like experience.

He candidly frames YouTube as a revenue channel rather than the creative goal: his passion is the game, and video topics are tested primarily for views and income (with some exceptions he finds interesting, like optimizations).
findings.quote: There’s two things I care about in life right now, professionally. The first is making my video game and the second is making money.

findings.summary: He confirms the "Chorus 1 demo" is still planned and mentions he may include a hidden unlockable Delfino Plaza area (Super Mario Sunshine) running on N64 within the demo as an easter egg.

He vents about Parallel Launcher and bundled graphics plugin behavior (controller mapping not working, game failing to boot reliably, and coin rendering issues), resisting community pressure to adopt it as his main setup.
findings.quote: Dude, this is so shit… I hate it.

findings.summary: Zeina is present enough in the workflow that Kaze directly blames/teases her for Blender/toolchain messiness and errors, highlighting their collaborative (and playful) day-to-day dynamic while developing.

He outlines how his conveyor/saw-like mechanics are implemented: conveyors are actors controlling Mario’s movement within a radius and collision type, while their visuals may be baked into level geometry—suggesting a split between gameplay actors and static geometry for performance/organization.

He criticizes Tears of the Kingdom’s design for offering many solutions but allowing a few overpowered strategies to trivialize most puzzles, and relates that to his own desire to avoid repetitive dominant strategies in his game’s challenge design.
findings.quote: When I played Tears of the Kingdom I felt like it was mentally abusive towards me. And I will not elaborate on this.

zeina.summary: Kaze references Zeina in the moment-to-moment pipeline (Blender errors, remaps), teasing her about messy setups and using the stream microphone as leverage in their banter—evidence of a shared, intertwined home/work environment during development.
zeina.quote: When you’re arguing, the person with the microphone always wins.

zeina.summary: Kaze describes a daily rhythm where he often starts working before breakfast while Zeina takes longer to get out of bed, hinting at how their household routine shapes work blocks.

findings.summary: Lilaa is repeatedly addressed as a regular; Kaze frames the stream as a "texture picking" session and jokes that Lilaa loves these, reflecting ongoing rapport with frequent community members shaping stream tone.

Sauraen is mentioned as a potential source of certain technical/toolchain issues (jokingly framed as "mean" to blame), indicating Kaze’s awareness of upstream/community engineering dependencies in his stack.

In the context of emulator security, Kaze claims only simpleflips has plausibly been affected because he plays unreleased/experimental hacks early, suggesting perceived risk is tied to using unknown ROMs rather than mainstream hacks.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: There’s two things I care about in life right now, professionally. The first is making my video game and the second is making money.
memorable_quotes.context: Explaining his priorities and why YouTube performance matters to him even if he likes a video creatively.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: As soon as the game becomes unrecognizable from how the casual gameplay of the game goes, then the speedrun is not fun anymore.
memorable_quotes.context: Speedrun design philosophy: he wants skips to be exciting but not dominate the whole run.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: When I played Tears of the Kingdom I felt like it was mentally abusive towards me. And I will not elaborate on this.
memorable_quotes.context: A provocative, character-revealing take used to explain his frustration with overpowered, repetitive solutions in puzzle design.

key_stories.title: Building the Arts & Crafts falling-platform race sub-area
key_stories.summary: Kaze outlines and begins implementing a modular sub-area for the cardboard/arts-and-crafts course. The space is meant to be an abyss/lava pit with colored cardboard platforms that fall when approached, later paired with saw hazards that activate by proximity to force continuous movement.
key_stories.challenge: Make a compelling platforming set piece that feels fast and tense, while also fitting the handmade/cardboard visual theme and staying readable/fair for players.
key_stories.process: He measures and places modular platform pieces, experiments with random colors, tunes gaps for difficulty, and plans saw placement/activation logic. He iterates by playtesting jumps, narrowing platforms, and deciding the final star should sit on a stable non-falling platform.
key_stories.outcome: The sub-area’s gameplay direction is established (falling platforms + proximity saws + race pacing), with difficulty tuned down from "too brutal" to acceptable; next steps are adding saws and finalizing floor visuals.

key_stories.title: Blender-to-engine scaling mismatch forces a rebuild
key_stories.summary: While trying to scale/parameterize platform pieces for variety, Kaze encounters confusing discrepancies between Blender transforms and how Mario 64 interprets the same data. After failed attempts to reconcile scale values and offsets, he opts to rebuild the platforms cleanly.
key_stories.challenge: Platform scaling and placement become unreliable due to transform/scale differences and potential parameter mistakes, undermining level iteration speed.
key_stories.process: He checks scale values, notices identical-looking pieces despite different scales, suspects translation/scale got mixed, and tests exports. He concludes the setup is "too messed up" and chooses to remake the geometry/placements rather than continue debugging the broken state.
key_stories.outcome: He abandons the corrupted/unclear configuration and resets to a simpler rebuild to restore predictable iteration.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m just gonna remake these platforms… it just didn’t work.

key_stories.title: Rejecting emulator-only hat tweaks and resisting option bloat
key_stories.summary: Kaze considers an emulator-only trick to shrink the hat texture to reduce visible pixelation/crustiness, then rejects it because it looks silly. He uses the moment to argue against adding lots of small options for minor visual preferences.
key_stories.challenge: Address emulator visual complaints without fragmenting presentation or adding endless settings.
key_stories.process: He prototypes an emulator-detection-based hat size swap (emulator vs N64), evaluates the look live, and weighs whether it should be a configurable option.
key_stories.outcome: He decides not to ship it and reiterates a design stance: fewer options, avoid catering to every tiny complaint.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m not adding options for every little baby thing.

key_stories.title: Parallel Launcher frustration vs community pressure
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrates issues with Parallel Launcher (boot/control problems and coin rendering with a bundled plugin) and pushes back against viewers telling him to use it. He characterizes the experience as buggy and aggravating despite acknowledging it may not be "garbage" overall.
key_stories.challenge: Choose a reliable emulator/toolchain for development/testing while community recommendations conflict with his observed stability and correctness.
key_stories.process: He tests controller input and boot behavior, compares to an alternative setup that boots, and notes rendering incompatibilities. He vents about being told to adopt tools that demonstrably fail in his use case.
key_stories.outcome: He remains unwilling to switch and frames the launcher as too quirky/unreliable for his needs right now.
key_stories.key_quote: Everyone’s telling me to use this, and it’s just… I hate it.

open_questions.topic: Course 14 visual direction (painted floor, cardboard materials)
open_questions.context: Kaze dislikes the current floor and wants a painted/handcrafted look without ugly repetition, but hasn’t committed to a concrete solution.
questions: What specific references (games, crafts, materials, Yoshi’s Island inspiration) are guiding the final texture/lighting look for the Arts & Crafts level?
How do you decide when a texture looks "painted" enough on real N64 hardware versus emulator?
Do you have a pipeline for procedural variation/anti-tiling on N64 constraints, or is it mostly handcrafted textures?

open_questions.topic: Falling platforms + proximity saws: final gameplay tuning
open_questions.context: He describes platforms that fall when approached and saws that start when close, aiming for a fast "race" feel.
questions: What exact trigger rules govern platform falling and saw activation (radius, timing, resets on death)?
How do you ensure the section stays fair for casual players while still feeling fast and tense?
How many variants of these modular platforms/hazards will appear across the full level or game?

open_questions.topic: B-params scaling system and overflow/underflow issues
open_questions.context: He scales platforms via actor parameters for variety but encountered overflow/underflow and rounding/fit issues.
questions: What were the precise overflow/underflow limits you hit (vertex count, bounds, color/lighting, display list size, collision limits)?
Is the scaling system a general-purpose engine feature you’ll reuse elsewhere, or a one-off for this level?
What final constraints/rules did you adopt (e.g., prefer multiple small pieces over scaling)?

open_questions.context: He observes major differences between how Blender applies scale/translation and how the game interprets it, leading to a rebuild.
questions: What is the root cause (exporter, coordinate system, fixed-point precision, actor scaling vs geometry scaling)?
How often do these Blender/engine mismatches cost you significant time across the project?
What safeguards or tooling changes would prevent this from happening again?

open_questions.topic: Dynamic UV scaling / procedural vertex generation plan
open_questions.context: To make textures behave correctly under scaling, he considers dynamically generating vertices so UV scale matches model scale.
questions: Did you implement dynamic UV/vertex generation, and if so where does it live (build step, runtime, custom tool)?
What are the performance/memory tradeoffs on N64 for this approach?
How do you validate visual parity between emulator and hardware once you do this?

open_questions.topic: Chorus 1 demo scope and hidden Delfino Plaza
open_questions.context: Kaze says the Chorus 1 demo is planned and he may hide Delfino Plaza as an unlockable secret in the demo.
questions: What is the target content list for the Chorus 1 demo (courses, stars, features, performance targets)?
Why include Delfino Plaza specifically—tech flex, nostalgia, tone-setting, or a broader hub/world idea?
What does "hide that really well" mean in practice (secret exit, condition, meta puzzle)?

open_questions.topic: Speedrun goals and anti-skip philosophy applied to level design
open_questions.context: He predicts longer speedrun times and argues against speedruns becoming unrecognizable from casual play; he also comments on BLJ frequency.
questions: What specific glitches/tech are you deliberately allowing, discouraging, or patching (BLJs, wall clips, unintended skips)?
Do you test levels with speedrunners or set internal rules for what’s acceptable?
How does this philosophy affect placement of invisible walls, slopes, and collision seams?

open_questions.topic: Emulator support strategy and toolchain standardization
open_questions.context: He rejects emulator-only hat changes, complains about Parallel Launcher/controller/coin rendering, and recommends common emulators as "probably fine."
questions: What is your official recommended emulator/setup for players of the demo/final release?
How do you test across emulator plugins vs real hardware to avoid graphical regressions (e.g., coin rendering)?
Will you ship any in-game toggles for emulator/hardware differences, or keep a single canonical presentation?

open_questions.topic: Conveyor/bomb production treadmill behavior (turns, corners, pathing)
open_questions.context: He explains conveyors as actor-driven push volumes, and discusses making a treadmill turn by using a drop-down or rounded corner to avoid bots getting stuck.
questions: How do moving hazards/enemies interact with conveyor volumes—do they use the same push logic as Mario?
What’s the final plan for conveyor corners (rounded collision, drop-down transitions, path nodes)?
Are conveyors and similar mechanics part of a reusable "actor toolkit" for many levels?

open_questions.topic: Kaze & Zeina workflow at home (pipeline ownership, humor vs friction)
open_questions.context: Kaze references Zeina in day-to-day work patterns and jokingly blames toolchain messiness; their banter suggests close collaboration.
questions: How do you split responsibilities between coding/level design/asset creation day-to-day?
When toolchain errors happen, how do you decide whether Kaze fixes it, Zeina fixes it, or you change the pipeline?
How has working as spouses affected productivity, conflict resolution, and creative decision-making during this project?
